s.text: It is probably true that we will need skillful librarians, and maybe even more librarians, in etopia.

The novelist Nicholson Baker, an eloquent critic of what libraries have done in the name of modernization, is certainly right about how foolish many great libraries were to destroy their card catalogs after transferring them to electronic form.
A friend of mine who used to teach in an overcrowded New York City school makes the point that for a lot of poor kids, the library is the only place to do homework after school.
Dick Brass, Microsoft's vice president for technology development, says that the technical hurdles of screen quality and battery life have been largely surmounted.
The day may be not so far off when we can accomplish this function better with a subsidized Internet account and a free digital reading device.
It is the more ordinary libraries--the 9,000 public and branch libraries in American towns and cities--that face a real threat of redundancy.
He merely uses an inefficient subsidy for something that is increasingly cheap and easy to do at home--and which could soon be subsidized directly at far lower expense.

And while e-books have tremendous appeal in theory--imagine an entire library that weighs a pound, is word-searchable, and can be read in the dark (and, at long last, a copy of Slate that you can take to the bathroom)--readers simply may not cotton to them.
That is not to say that these institutions don't have functions beyond lending out books.
Brass predicts that you'll be able to get 50,000 titles electronically--more than you can find in an average Barnes & Noble franchise--in two years.
